awd_titl_txt: Convergence RAISE: Harnessing Extracellular Vesicle Mediated Interkingdom Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is about integrating complex, interdisciplinary science to better understand how communication works, at a cellular level, between different kingdoms, and how cells actively shape their environments. Specifically, work will focus on how fungal, microbial, and plant cells communicate between and affect each other and surrounding soil systems. One known mechanism enabling inter-kingdom communication is that cells secrete nanoscale structures called extracellular vesicles. These extremely small sub-cellular objects play a role in transporting packages of genetic and chemical materials that are used to communicate with other cells, and to affect the interactions of other living and non-living entities in their environments. What remains poorly understood are which biological and environmental factors govern extracellular vesicle release, what "cargo" they carry, where they are transported, whether they transform along the way, how and if they reach their targets, and their ultimate effects. The potential implications of being able to understand and manipulate extracellular vesicles in the environment are enormous; these interactions can have significant impacts on agriculture, wastewater treatment, contaminant clean-up, microbiomes, and other critical systems. Investigating the mechanisms of inter-kingdom communication is only possible with a confluence of expertise ranging across widely disparate disciplines, and therefore this project includes researchers from biochemistry, environmental microbiology, colloid science, nanoscale fate and transport, biogeochemistry, molecular biology, mycology, soil science, data science, and one integrating discipline called integration and implementation science. The project will also study how effective applied integration and implementation science methods are at enabling and improving co-creation of knowledge at the intersection of disciplines. The broader impacts of this research involve training of graduate students, broadening participation of underrepresented minority students, and performing outreach to elementary students and the general public in museums.

This effort addresses the biological basis for inter-kingdom communication via vesicle transport, the impact of geochemistry on vesicle mediated communication, and the biophysical parameters and surface properties of vesicles that lead to interkingdom biological interactions. The convergence of biochemistry, nanoparticle surface properties, and soil geochemistry is unique in studies of bacterial/fungal/plant interactions within the native soil environment. Consequently, the overall intellectual merit of this project is two fold: the advancement of knowledge to bridge the gaps in diverse fields of study, and a transformative approach to interdisciplinary research. Goals of the work include intertwining and blending expertise across disparate disciplines to elucidate fungal and bacterial extracellular vesicle generation and transport processes as a basis for engineering improved control strategies. To achieve these goals, the following objectives will be pursued: 1) Identify and characterize extracellular vesicles (e.g. surface chemistry and biological cargo) involved in the interaction of fungi, bacteria, and plant cells in soil systems; 2) Investigate the effects of the surrounding media conditions on extracellular vesicles, 3) Investigate the biological effects imparted by extracellular vesicles between bacteria and fungi under environmental conditions relevant to fungal-bacterial-plant interactions in soil and rhizosphere systems; 4) Use this information to engineer soft colloid vehicles for delivering diverse macromolecular cargo to cells in applications ranging from agriculture to contaminated sediment remediation, and 5) Pilot and qualitatively evaluate the effectiveness of interdisciplinary integration communication methods, conceptual frameworks, and knowledge building tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report:

The Convergence RAISE: Harnessing Extracellular Vesicle Mediated Interkingdom Communication spanned a total of four years, steered collaboratively by co-PIs representing diverse areas of expertise to integrate methods and knowledge across interconnected questions. Our goal was to better understand the physical and biological factors that impact the fate, transport, and impacts of nanoscale biological particles and their roles in cellular communication between kingdoms, particularly in systems that include bacteria, fungi, and plants. Disciplinary fields included biogeochemistry, molecular biology, nanomaterial and colloid behavior in environmental systems, and integration and implementation science (I2S). Throughout the arc of the project, the PI coordinated integration across and between the project participants, and three primary faculty co-PIs each served primary advisors within a core group of 4 doctoral students whose committees also included other project co-PIs/PI. The resulting dissertations and doctoral study journeys surfaced and addressed novel research questions at the intersections between fields of study, joined by the shared interest in how nanoscale biological particles participate in intercellular and interkingdom communication. Collectively this work generated blended methods and epistemologies, or ways of thinking, which resulted in new knowledge at the intersection of fields, as well as new convergent capacities for trainees and mentors alike. In addition to these core participants, multiple other doctoral students, masters’ students, and undergraduates also contributed to the project team as well.

The project's transdisciplinary efforts have fostered a deeper understanding of EV behavior, setting the stage for predictive modeling in environmental systems. This understanding extends to evaluating risks associated with microbial and viral symbionts, potentially influencing environmental management strategies. Overall, the project has contributed approaches and insights useful to evaluating environmental systems interactions with nanoscale biological particles, the impacts of which can extend beyond scientific and technological advancements to potentially influence societal strategies in environmental management, agricultural practices, and public health measures. Furthermore, integrative methods, educational initiatives and outreach activities have strengthened the link between science and society, enhancing scientific literacy and public engagement.

 

1.     Isolating and Characterizing Nano-Scale Biological Materials:

  • Identified helpful bacterial vesicles strengthening plant disease resistance.
  • Developed methods to measure and describe EV surfaces consistently, so we can use this information in predictive modeling of EV transport in varied conditions.
  • Explored these vesicles' effectiveness even when fragmented or separated, robustness allowing these vesicles to navigate diverse environments.
  • A focus on preparing purified EVs from diverse bacterial strains in different media unveiled distinct bacterial EV subpopulations, hinting at unique functionalities and implications for plant host cell reactivity.

2.     Investigating Media Effects and Bacteria-Fungi Interactions on EVs:

  • Introduced a method to estimate nanoscale bio-colloid contributions to surface acidity, yielding insights into nanoparticle surface properties compared to parent cells.
  • Examined changes in vesicle properties and behaviors upon interaction with varied environmental conditions.
  • Identified environmental factors affecting vesicle behavior, such as pH and ionic composition.

3.     Characterizing Effects of EVs in Complex Systems:

  • Developed models showcasing the protective effects of EVs on plants.
  • Improved soil-specific methods for studying vesicles, enhancing understanding of their behavior.
  • Ongoing investigations on EVs from soil bacteria and fungi's impact on Arabidopsis thaliana seeds aim to understand plant growth impacts and rhizospheric community structures.

4.     Interdisciplinary Integration and Outreach

  • Students actively engaged in interdisciplinary collaboration, method development, data analysis, and interpretation, gaining proficiency in experimental methodologies and scientific dissemination.
  • Undergraduate researchers participated in outreach initiatives, honing communication skills and fostering scientific literacy among K-12 students.
  • Through collaboration that spanned all career phases, the project team collectively modeled and shared experiences of learning entirely new areas of research, in the process unearthing new questions, making methodological advancements, and creating a new nexus of biology, environmental science, and societal engagement focused on nanoscale biological particles in plant-soil-water systems.

Overall Impact Beyond Science and Technology

The project's multidisciplinary efforts have fostered a deeper understanding of EV behavior, setting the stage for predictive modeling in environmental systems. This understanding extends to evaluating risks associated with microbial and viral symbionts, potentially influencing environmental management strategies. Overall, the project has contributed approaches and insights useful to evaluating environmental systems interactions with nanoscale biological particles, the impacts of which can extend beyond scientific and technological advancements to potentially influence societal strategies in environmental management, agricultural practices, and public health measures. Furthermore, integrative methods, educational initiatives and outreach activities have strengthened the link between science and society, enhancing scientific literacy and public engagement.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2024
Modified by: Christine O Hendren
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Outcome Report:


The Convergence RAISE: Harnessing Extracellular Vesicle Mediated Interkingdom Communication spanned a total of four years, steered collaboratively by co-PIs representing diverse areas of expertise to integrate methods and knowledge across interconnected questions. Our goal was to better understand the physical and biological factors that impact the fate, transport, and impacts of nanoscale biological particles and their roles in cellular communication between kingdoms, particularly in systems that include bacteria, fungi, and plants. Disciplinary fields included biogeochemistry, molecular biology, nanomaterial and colloid behavior in environmental systems, and integration and implementation science (I2S). Throughout the arc of the project, the PI coordinated integration across and between the project participants, and three primary faculty co-PIs each served primary advisors within a core group of 4 doctoral students whose committees also included other project co-PIs/PI. The resulting dissertations and doctoral study journeys surfaced and addressed novel research questions at the intersections between fields of study, joined by the shared interest in how nanoscale biological particles participate in intercellular and interkingdom communication. Collectively this work generated blended methods and epistemologies, or ways of thinking, which resulted in new knowledge at the intersection of fields, as well as new convergent capacities for trainees and mentors alike. In addition to these core participants, multiple other doctoral students, masters students, and undergraduates also contributed to the project team as well.


The project's transdisciplinary efforts have fostered a deeper understanding of EV behavior, setting the stage for predictive modeling in environmental systems. This understanding extends to evaluating risks associated with microbial and viral symbionts, potentially influencing environmental management strategies. Overall, the project has contributed approaches and insights useful to evaluating environmental systems interactions with nanoscale biological particles, the impacts of which can extend beyond scientific and technological advancements to potentially influence societal strategies in environmental management, agricultural practices, and public health measures. Furthermore, integrative methods, educational initiatives and outreach activities have strengthened the link between science and society, enhancing scientific literacy and public engagement.





1. Isolating and Characterizing Nano-Scale Biological Materials:

Identified helpful bacterial vesicles strengthening plant disease resistance.
Developed methods to measure and describe EV surfaces consistently, so we can use this information in predictive modeling of EV transport in varied conditions.
Explored these vesicles' effectiveness even when fragmented or separated, robustness allowing these vesicles to navigate diverse environments.
A focus on preparing purified EVs from diverse bacterial strains in different media unveiled distinct bacterial EV subpopulations, hinting at unique functionalities and implications for plant host cell reactivity.



2. Investigating Media Effects and Bacteria-Fungi Interactions on EVs:

Introduced a method to estimate nanoscale bio-colloid contributions to surface acidity, yielding insights into nanoparticle surface properties compared to parent cells.
Examined changes in vesicle properties and behaviors upon interaction with varied environmental conditions.
Identified environmental factors affecting vesicle behavior, such as pH and ionic composition.



3. Characterizing Effects of EVs in Complex Systems:

Developed models showcasing the protective effects of EVs on plants.
Improved soil-specific methods for studying vesicles, enhancing understanding of their behavior.
Ongoing investigations on EVs from soil bacteria and fungi's impact on Arabidopsis thaliana seeds aim to understand plant growth impacts and rhizospheric community structures.



4. Interdisciplinary Integration and Outreach

Students actively engaged in interdisciplinary collaboration, method development, data analysis, and interpretation, gaining proficiency in experimental methodologies and scientific dissemination.
Undergraduate researchers participated in outreach initiatives, honing communication skills and fostering scientific literacy among K-12 students.
Through collaboration that spanned all career phases, the project team collectively modeled and shared experiences of learning entirely new areas of research, in the process unearthing new questions, making methodological advancements, and creating a new nexus of biology, environmental science, and societal engagement focused on nanoscale biological particles in plant-soil-water systems.



Overall Impact Beyond Science and Technology


The project's multidisciplinary efforts have fostered a deeper understanding of EV behavior, setting the stage for predictive modeling in environmental systems. This understanding extends to evaluating risks associated with microbial and viral symbionts, potentially influencing environmental management strategies. Overall, the project has contributed approaches and insights useful to evaluating environmental systems interactions with nanoscale biological particles, the impacts of which can extend beyond scientific and technological advancements to potentially influence societal strategies in environmental management, agricultural practices, and public health measures. Furthermore, integrative methods, educational initiatives and outreach activities have strengthened the link between science and society, enhancing scientific literacy and public engagement.
